text: The primary theme of Hebrews is the superiority of whom/what?
options: Christ and the New Covenant over the Old Covenant system
verseText: Long ago, at many times and in many ways, God spoke to our fathers by the prophets, but in these last days he has spoken to us by his Son... He is the radiance of the glory of God... After making purification for sins, he sat down at the right hand of the Majesty on high... But as it is, Christ has obtained a ministry that is as much more excellent than the old as the covenant he mediates is better, since it is enacted on better promises.

text: How does Hebrews 1 describe the Son's relationship to the angels?
options: He is one of the angels
He is inferior to the angels
He is superior to the angels
He is equal to the angels
verseText: having become as much superior to angels as the name he has inherited is more excellent than theirs. For to which of the angels did God ever say, “You are my Son, today I have begotten you”?

text: Hebrews emphasizes Jesus' role as a great...
verseText: Since then we have a great high priest who has passed through the heavens, Jesus, the Son of God, let us hold fast our confession.

text: According to Hebrews 4:12, the word of God is described as what?
options: Living and active, sharper than any two-edged sword
verseText: For the word of God is living and active, sharper than any two-edged sword, piercing to the division of soul and of spirit, of joints and of marrow, and discerning the thoughts and intentions of the heart.

text: Who is the mysterious priest-king mentioned in Hebrews 7, to whom Abraham paid tithes, and whose priesthood is compared to Christ's?
verseText: For this Melchizedek, king of Salem, priest of the Most High God, met Abraham returning from the slaughter of the kings and blessed him... He is without father or mother or genealogy, having neither beginning of days nor end of life, but resembling the Son of God he continues a priest forever... For it is witnessed of him, “You are a priest forever, after the order of Melchizedek.”

text: What does Hebrews 9 contrast regarding the Old and New Covenants?
options: The earthly tabernacle and sacrifices with Christ's heavenly ministry and perfect sacrifice
The roles of priests and kings
verseText: But when Christ appeared as a high priest of the good things that have come, then through the greater and more perfect tent (not made with hands...)... he entered once for all into the holy places, not by means of the blood of goats and calves but by means of his own blood, thus securing an eternal redemption... For Christ has entered, not into holy places made with hands, which are copies of the true things, but into heaven itself...

text: What is the definition of faith given in Hebrews 11:1?
options: The assurance of things hoped for, the conviction of things not seen
verseText: Now faith is the assurance of things hoped for, the conviction of things not seen.

text: Hebrews chapter 11 is often called the 'Hall of Faith' because it lists examples of Old Testament figures who...
verseText: By faith Abel offered to God a more acceptable sacrifice than Cain, through which he was commended as righteous, God commending him by accepting his gifts. And through his faith, though he died, he still speaks. By faith Enoch was taken up so that he should not see death, and he was not found, because God had taken him. Now before he was taken he was commended as having pleased God. By faith Noah, being warned by God concerning events as yet unseen, in reverent fear constructed an ark for the saving of his household. By this he condemned the world and became an heir of the righteousness that comes by faith. By faith Abraham obeyed when he was called to go out to a place that he was to receive as an inheritance. And he went out, not knowing where he was going.

text: According to Hebrews 12, how should believers respond to God's discipline?
options: Endure it, recognizing it as training from a loving Father
verseText: It is for discipline that you have to endure. God is treating you as sons. For what son is there whom his father does not discipline?... For the moment all discipline seems painful rather than pleasant, but later it yields the peaceful fruit of righteousness to those who have been trained by it.

text: What does Hebrews 13:8 declare about Jesus Christ?
options: He is the same yesterday and today and forever
He is only relevant for the past
verseText: Jesus Christ is the same yesterday and today and forever.

text: In the opening of Hebrews, how did God speak 'in these last days' that contrasts with how He spoke in the past?
verseText: Long ago, at many times and in many ways, God spoke to our fathers by the prophets, but in these last days he has spoken to us by his Son...

text: What position did the Son take after making purification for sins?
options: He sat down at the right hand of the Majesty on high
verseText: He is the radiance of the glory of God and the exact imprint of his nature... After making purification for sins, he sat down at the right hand of the Majesty on high,

text: Hebrews 2 warns against neglecting what?
verseText: Therefore we must pay much closer attention to what we have heard, lest we drift away from it... how shall we escape if we neglect such a great salvation?

text: Why did Jesus have to be made like His brothers (human) in every respect?
options: To become a merciful and faithful high priest
verseText: Therefore he had to be made like his brothers in every respect, so that he might become a merciful and faithful high priest in the service of God, to make propitiation for the sins of the people.

text: Because Jesus Himself suffered when tempted, what is He able to do for those who are tempted?
verseText: For because he himself has suffered when tempted, he is able to help those who are being tempted.

text: Hebrews 3 compares Jesus to which Old Testament figure, showing Jesus' superiority as the Son over the house compared to a servant in the house?
verseText: Therefore, holy brothers... consider Jesus, the apostle and high priest of our confession... Jesus has been counted worthy of more glory than Moses—as much more glory as the builder of a house has more honor than the house itself... Now Moses was faithful in all God's house as a servant... but Christ is faithful over God's house as a son.

text: What warning does Hebrews 3 give, referencing the Israelites in the wilderness?
options: Not to harden their hearts and rebel
verseText: Therefore, as the Holy Spirit says, “Today, if you hear his voice, do not harden your hearts as in the rebellion...” As it is said, “Today, if you hear his voice, do not harden your hearts as in the rebellion.”

text: What 'rest' remains for the people of God, according to Hebrews 4?
options: A Sabbath rest (referring to salvation and eternal rest)
verseText: So then, there remains a Sabbath rest for the people of God, for whoever has entered God's rest has also rested from his works as God did from his.

text: Why can believers draw near to the throne of grace with confidence?
options: Because Jesus, our High Priest, sympathizes with our weaknesses
verseText: For we do not have a high priest who is unable to sympathize with our weaknesses, but one who in every respect has been tempted as we are, yet without sin. Let us then with confidence draw near to the throne of grace, that we may receive mercy and find grace to help in time of need.

text: What qualification did Old Testament high priests need, which Jesus also demonstrated through His suffering?
options: Ability to sympathize with the ignorant and wayward
verseText: For every high priest chosen from among men is appointed to act on behalf of men in relation to God... He can deal gently with the ignorant and wayward, since he himself is beset with weakness.

text: How did Jesus learn obedience, according to Hebrews 5?
verseText: Although he was a son, he learned obedience through what he suffered.

text: The author of Hebrews chastises the readers for being 'dull of hearing' and needing what, when they ought to be teachers?
verseText: About this we have much to say, and it is hard to explain, since you have become dull of hearing. For though by this time you ought to be teachers, you need someone to teach you again the basic principles of the oracles of God. You need milk, not solid food,

text: Hebrews 6 warns that it is impossible to restore to repentance those who have once been enlightened, tasted the heavenly gift, shared in the Holy Spirit, tasted the goodness of God's word and the powers of the age to come, and then done what?
verseText: For it is impossible, in the case of those who have once been enlightened, who have tasted the heavenly gift, and have shared in the Holy Spirit, and have tasted the goodness of the word of God and the powers of the age to come, and then have fallen away, to restore them again to repentance, since they are crucifying once again the Son of God to their own harm and holding him up to contempt.

text: What does God's promise and oath provide for the believer's hope?
options: Strong encouragement and an anchor for the soul
verseText: so that by two unchangeable things, in which it is impossible for God to lie, we who have fled for refuge might have strong encouragement to hold fast to the hope set before us. We have this as a sure and steadfast anchor of the soul...

text: Why is the priesthood of Melchizedek superior to the Levitical priesthood, according to Hebrews 7?
options: Levi paid tithes to Melchizedek through Abraham
verseText: See how great this man was to whom Abraham the patriarch gave a tenth of the spoils!... One might even say that Levi himself, who receives tithes, paid tithes through Abraham, for he was still in the loins of his ancestor when Melchizedek met him.

text: What key difference between Christ's priesthood and the Levitical priesthood relates to permanence?
options: Christ is a priest forever, while Levitical priests died
verseText: The former priests were many in number, because they were prevented by death from continuing in office, but he holds his priesthood permanently, because he continues forever.

text: Because Christ lives forever to intercede, He is able to do what for those who draw near to God through Him?
verseText: Consequently, he is able to save to the uttermost those who draw near to God through him, since he always lives to make intercession for them.

text: What is the main deficiency of the Old Covenant that necessitated a New Covenant?
options: It could not perfect the conscience or truly take away sins; it had fault
verseText: For if that first covenant had been faultless, there would have been no occasion to look for a second... For the law... can never, by the same sacrifices that are continually offered every year, make perfect those who draw near... For it is impossible for the blood of bulls and goats to take away sins.

text: Where does the New Covenant promise that God's laws will be written?
verseText: For this is the covenant that I will make with the house of Israel after those days, declares the Lord: I will put my laws into their minds, and write them on their hearts...

text: What did the regulations of the first covenant's tabernacle primarily pertain to?
options: Food, drink, and various washings—external regulations
verseText: (Which is symbolic for the present age.) According to this arrangement, gifts and sacrifices are offered that cannot perfect the conscience of the worshiper, but deal only with food and drink and various washings, regulations for the body imposed until the time of reformation.

text: How often did the high priest enter the Most Holy Place under the Old Covenant, and with what?
verseText: but into the second only the high priest goes, and he but once a year, and not without taking blood, which he offers for himself and for the unintentional sins of the people.

text: According to Hebrews 9:22, without the shedding of what is there no forgiveness of sins?
verseText: Indeed, under the law almost everything is purified with blood, and without the shedding of blood there is no forgiveness of sins.

text: How many times did Christ have to offer Himself as a sacrifice for sins?
verseText: But as it is, he has appeared once for all at the end of the ages to put away sin by the sacrifice of himself... so Christ, having been offered once to bear the sins of many... And by that will we have been sanctified through the offering of the body of Jesus Christ once for all.

text: What is Christ doing now at God's right hand after offering His sacrifice?
options: Waiting until His enemies are made His footstool
verseText: But when Christ had offered for all time a single sacrifice for sins, he sat down at the right hand of God, waiting from that time until his enemies should be made a footstool for his feet.

text: What should believers provoke one another to, according to Hebrews 10?
verseText: And let us consider how to stir up one another to love and good works,

text: Hebrews 10 warns believers not to neglect what practice?
verseText: not neglecting to meet together, as is the habit of some, but encouraging one another, and all the more as you see the Day drawing near.

text: What fearful thing awaits those who deliberately go on sinning after receiving the knowledge of the truth?
options: A fearful expectation of judgment and fury of fire
verseText: For if we go on sinning deliberately after receiving the knowledge of the truth, there no longer remains a sacrifice for sins, but a fearful expectation of judgment, and a fury of fire that will consume the adversaries.

text: By faith, who offered a more acceptable sacrifice than Cain?
verseText: By faith Abel offered to God a more acceptable sacrifice than Cain, through which he was commended as righteous...

text: By faith, who constructed an ark for the saving of his household?
verseText: By faith Noah, being warned by God concerning events as yet unseen, in reverent fear constructed an ark for the saving of his household.

text: By faith, Abraham looked forward to what?
options: The city that has foundations, whose designer and builder is God
verseText: For he was looking forward to the city that has foundations, whose designer and builder is God.

text: By faith, who chose to be mistreated with the people of God rather than enjoy the fleeting pleasures of sin?
verseText: By faith Moses, when he was grown up, refused to be called the son of Pharaoh's daughter, choosing rather to be mistreated with the people of God than to enjoy the fleeting pleasures of sin.

text: By faith, the walls of what city fell down after being encircled for seven days?
verseText: By faith the walls of Jericho fell down after they had been encircled for seven days.

text: Hebrews 11 mentions heroes of faith who experienced great victories, but also those who experienced what?
verseText: Some were tortured, refusing to accept release, so that they might rise again to a better life. Others suffered mocking and flogging, and even chains and imprisonment. They were stoned, they were sawn in two, they were killed with the sword. They went about in skins of sheep and goats, destitute, afflicted, mistreated—of whom the world was not worthy—wandering about in deserts and mountains, and in dens and caves of the earth.

text: What are believers encouraged to lay aside in the race set before them?
options: Every weight, and sin which clings so closely
verseText: Therefore, since we are surrounded by so great a cloud of witnesses, let us also lay aside every weight, and sin which clings so closely, and let us run with endurance the race that is set before us,

text: Where should believers fix their eyes while running the race?
options: On Jesus, the founder and perfecter of our faith
verseText: looking to Jesus, the founder and perfecter of our faith, who for the joy that was set before him endured the cross, despising the shame, and is seated at the right hand of the throne of God.

text: Hebrews 12 contrasts the terrifying experience of the Israelites at Mount Sinai with the believers' approach to what?
options: Mount Zion and the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem
verseText: For you have not come to what may be touched, a blazing fire... But you have come to Mount Zion and to the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, and to innumerable angels in festal gathering,

text: What practical exhortation is given regarding brotherly love in Hebrews 13?
verseText: Let brotherly love continue.

text: What attitude should believers have towards money and possessions, according to Hebrews 13?
options: Be content with what they have
verseText: Keep your life free from love of money, and be content with what you have, for he has said, “I will never leave you nor forsake you.”

text: Where did Jesus suffer (be crucified) in relation to the city gate, and what does this signify for believers?
options: Outside the gate, signifying rejection and bearing reproach
verseText: So Jesus also suffered outside the gate in order to sanctify the people through his own blood. Therefore let us go to him outside the camp and bear the reproach he endured.

text: What kind of sacrifice is pleasing to God, mentioned in Hebrews 13 after discussing Christ's sacrifice?
verseText: Through him then let us continually offer up a sacrifice of praise to God, that is, the fruit of lips that acknowledge his name. Do not neglect to do good and to share what you have, for such sacrifices are pleasing to God.
